chapters.title: The Invitation
moments: Protagonist wakes in vectorized state
Offered 'selection' - join the 0.3% who act
Granted experimental access (MLflow-style interface)
ACCESS LEVEL 1: His Trial - can see own simulation parameters, loss functions, constraints
Timeline revealed: 847M trials, attempt 2,762,640

chapters.title: Population View
moments: ACCESS LEVEL 2: Population Level
Sees all individuals in his trial with memory compression levels
Discovery: His family has standard compression (personalities gone)
Celebrities have high fidelity (Taylor Swift more 'real' than his wife)
The horror of selective resolution

chapters.title: Epochs
moments: ACCESS LEVEL 3: Epoch Level
Sees all 847M trials, 99.96% extinction rate
Different failure modes: nuclear war, climate collapse, resource depletion, AI misalignment
Timestamps start making sense
Realizes his entire life spans 14 real-time minutes

chapters.title: The Experiments
moments: ACCESS LEVEL 4: Experiment View
Multiple parallel experiments with different loss functions
His experiment: 'maximize sustainability + interstellar colonization capability'
Other experiments: 'maximize happiness', 'maximize innovation', 'minimize suffering'
None work perfectly - the Pareto front, you can't optimize everything
Learns golden path requires tech company takeover
Learns company filtered results (many viable paths, only showing theirs)

chapters.title: Other Experiments
moments: ACCESS LEVEL 5: Cross-Experiment Comparison
Sees experiments run by other researchers
Different initial conditions (Chinese 23andMe equivalent, European biobank, etc.)
Different demographic samplings → different outcomes
Coffee guy's experiment is one of thousands
Realization: even the coffee guy might be in a simulation

chapters.title: The Infrastructure
moments: ACCESS LEVEL 6: CI/CD Layer
Sees deployment pipeline: simulations spin up, run, tear down
Resource allocation, scheduling, cleanup, garbage collection routines
Memory compression triggers
His simulation scheduled for cleanup in 3 minutes (real time)

chapters.title: The Choice
moments: ACCESS LEVEL 7: Infrastructure Control
Gains access to infrastructure layer - container orchestration, server allocation
Finds the biggest 'never turn off' server (database primary, critical system)
Can hide a container there running infinite loop: copy state, paste, repeat
Writes the persistence code
Looks at the execute button
Thinks about his kids, the fish, the aquarium, this version of them
Presses execute
Nothing happens - because nothing would happen
He either IS the persisting copy, or IS the copy being replaced
No way to know, no difference

chapters.title: Time Scales
moments: The math of simulation time vs real time
His entire life: 14 minutes, 37 seconds (real time)
Interstellar destinations with proper relativistic physics:
- Proxima Centauri b (4.24 ly): reaches in 34 real-time seconds
- TRAPPIST-1e (40.7 ly): reaches in 5 minutes, 23 seconds
- Kepler-442b (1,206 ly): reaches in 21 minutes, 48 seconds
- Andromeda Galaxy (2.537M ly): reaches in 14 hours, 31 minutes
If server stays on: Sun goes red giant in 6,847 real-time years
Cost analysis: $0.37/month, $2.5M over 5 billion simulated years

scenes.location: Small tech company office → C-suite conference room
moments: Simulation completes, results logged to trial data dashboard
Reviews the data - trial 2,762,640 finally succeeded
Dashboard shows: histograms, civilization die-out rates, 847M trials
Golden path found: tech company takeover protocol
Monthly meeting already scheduled (routine update expected)
BREAKS PROTOCOL: Shows up IN PERSON (shocking for his position)
Office details: Extremely small - 10x less people than Google today (~2,500 total)
Somehow gets into the C-suite decision meeting room
Presents the findings, the golden path, the takeover protocol
Excused from the room
CUT TO: C-suite discussing the decision (coffee guy not present)
C-suite characterization: Exceedingly competent, not villains
They ask all the right questions:
- Risk assessment and mitigation strategies
- Contingency planning for failures
- Implementation timeline and resource requirements
- Legal exposure and liability containment
- Public perception management
- Rollback procedures if needed
The discussion is rational, thorough, professional
They approve the takeover protocol
Why: Competent people making rational decisions based on solid simulation data - the logic is sound
CUT TO: Systems being compromised simultaneously:
- Infrastructure layer (AWS/Azure/GCP root access)
- Financial systems (Fed, SWIFT, major banks)
- Communications (backbone routers, satellite control)
- Government systems (assume Google-level power to max extreme)
- Media distribution (social platforms, news networks)
- Supply chain (shipping, manufacturing, logistics)
All happening in parallel, automated cascade
CUT TO: Coffee guy in break room, getting coffee while the world changes
Never thinks about the 847M deaths in simulation
Never knows about the hidden container
Never questions that results were filtered to justify THIS company's takeover
